description.narrative: 1. Number of issues regarding the oversight function that are considered by NARS annually; number of reports of independent bodies that are considered 2. Number of public scrutiny hearings; Number of mobile committee sessions; public opinion poll findings; pilot municipal assemblies receive feedback from citizens (y/n). 3. Portal for tracking public finances developed y/n

comment.narrative: 1. Increase in the number of issues scrutinized by the Parliament by 20%; all reports of independent bodies duly processed in line with the Rules Procedure. 2. Overall increase recorded in the number of public hearings and mobile committee sessions held annually in relation to the project baseline; increase in trust in the National Assembly as per the public opinion poll from 8 % in 2008 to 23% in 2015; 5 pilot municipal assemblies have developed mechanisms for engaging citizens' opinions. 3. Portal for monitoring public budget expenditure developed and tested, data transfer secured and MPs and staff trained.

description.narrative: Finance Sector Policy Coordination Framework
Finance Sector Policy Coordination Framework
seat of a third-order administrative division

1. Continuous trainings in relevant fields conducted. 2. Action Plan for Harmonization and Integration of Project Financing (public debt, WBWF, and IPA funds) adopted by the Ministry. 3. Annual Report on State Aid for 2011 adopted and posted on the official website of the Ministry. 4. ICT Strategy adopted by the Ministry.

comment.narrative: 1. Insufficient capacity of the Ministry in certain specific areas of expertise necessary for continuation of structural reforms 2. No existing Action Plan for harmonization and integration of project financing (public debt, WBWF, and IPA funds). 3. No existing Annual Report on State Aid for 2011. 4. No existing ICT Strategy of the Ministry.

description.narrative: Strengtening Capacity for Inclusive Local Development in South Serbia (Multi Donor funded UN Joint Programme)
Strengthening Capacity for Inclusive Local Development in South Serbia
seat of a third-order administrative division
Accountability - local government finance

1. Number of regional development projects selected and 50% implemented by the end of 2011 2. Number of areas where capacities of RDAs are strengthened. 3. Number of municipal development strategies revised with M&E systems. 4. Number of new partnerships between municipalities and CSOs advanced through joint projects. 5. Quality and reach of services of the Ombudsman Office in South Serbia.

comment.narrative: 1. Municipalities develop projects individually, without cooperation at regional level. 2. RDAs capacity limited especially in financial management (based on interviews with other donors). RDAs established relatively recently (2008). 3. Municipal development strategies mainly expired and do not have M&E systems. 4. Partnership of municipalities and CSOs is rare and weak. 5. Activities of the Ombudsman Office suffer from lack of awareness about their services and limited capacities. Offices in Bujanovac, Presevo and Medvedja are to be established in 2011.

description.narrative: Policy Advice for Good Governance outcome
Preparation of the National Human Development Report
1. Compliance with corporate NHDR preparation standards: national ownership, participatory and inclusive preparation, independence and quality of analysis, flexibility and creativity in presentation

comment.narrative: Last National Human Development Report (NHDR) was published in 2010. In the context of post 2014 floods that havily hit Serbia, there was a requirement to prepare a new one which will provide policy advice and actionable recommendations towards greater resilience of communities
1. Construct Capitals for Resilience Index; finalise outline and methodology; select 13 municipalities for qualitative reseach
1. Capitals for Resilience Index developed and all Serbian municipalities ranked; outline and methodology finalized; field visits to 13 municipaities started

title.narrative: National BD Planning for Implementing CBD Strategic Plan

description.narrative: National Biodiversity Planning to Support the Implementation of the CBD Strategic Plan in Serbia aims to integrate obligations under UNCBD into country’s national, development and sectoral planning frameworks in line with the CBD Strategic Plan 2011-2020
National Biodiversity Planning to Support the implementation of the CBD 2011-2020 Strategic Plan in the Republic of Serbia (NBSAP2)
seat of a third-order administrative division
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Status of NBSAP vis-à-vis the guidance in the CBD Strategic Plan (2011-2020) 2. Development of national targets in response to the global Aichi Targets 3. Status of national reporting to the CBD 4. Mainstreaming of biodiversity into sectors - renewable energy and spatial planning 5. Status of the national clearinghouse mechanism (CHM)

comment.narrative: 1. New CBD Strategic plan (2011-2020) is only partially reflected in the current National Biodiversity Planning 2. National biodiversity targets are not fully in line with the global Aichi targets 3. Fifth National Report to the Convention on Biological Diversity is not prepared 4. Biodiversity principles are not adequately integrated into national sectoral planning and development frameworks 5. National Clearing House Mechanism (CHM) needs improved linkage to the CBD’s global CHM networks and to other information and knowledge exchange network

1.National biodiversity planning consultations implemented 2.National biodiversity targets in response to the global Aichi Targets developed 3.National biodiversity indicators developed 4.Action Plan to achieve national targets developed 5.Text of the National Biodiversity Strategy revised

1.National biodiversity planning consultations conducted 2.Draft national biodiversity targets developed in response to the global Aichi targets 3.Draft biodiversity indicators developed in participatory manner 4. Draft Action Plan to achieve national targets prepared 5. Draft text of the revised Biodiversity Strategy prepared

1. Revised National Biodiversity Strategy in line with CBD Strategic Plan (2011-2020) finalized 2. Final national biodiversity targets in response to the global Aichi Targets and associated indicators developed 3. Action Plan to achieve national biodiversity targets finalized 4. National clearinghouse mechanism (CHM) updated

comment.narrative: 1. Lack of community-based sport initiatives for children from different social and ethnic groups. 2. Inter-ethnic distance among youth is high. Poor inter personal relations between Roma, Serbs and Bosniaks. Low level of social activism among youth in Sandzak. Sandzak youth reluctant to visit places outside the region. 3.There is no digital map of Sandzak. 4. There are no panel discussions or any other forms of Inter-ethnic and inter-religious dialogue between different ethnic groups in Sandzak. 5.People in the Sandzak region are not sufficiently informed about Human Security concept

description.narrative: Improved capability of local municipalities and entrepreneurs to identify, prioritize and develop biomass investment opportunities in Serbia

1. Established Biomass Support Unit
2. Training Modules and seminars on Biomass Energy for local municipalities and entrepreneurs based upon the UNDP Municipal Biomass Guide and Guide for Investors
3. New course on Biomass Energy at the University of Belgrade & Novi Sad
4. Public awareness raising campaign on Biomass Energy
4.1 Annual International workshop
5.Support to development of the biomass market
5.1 Biomass e-trade platform

comment.narrative:
1. No Biomass Support Unit
2. No training or study courses on Biomass to Energy issues
3. No guidance in development of biomass projects or previous experience
4. Currently no university training or study courses on Biomass to Energy issues
5. Limited awareness about climate change issues
6. No biomass e-trading platform

1. Biomass Support Unit staffed and in full operation with funding to continue after project ends
2. At least 12 completed regional seminars on biomass energy that employed the designed training module will be presented
3. Established courses on biomass at Universities Belgrade and Novi Sad
Regularly organized and conducted Annual International Workshop on Biomass Energy in Serbia produced by the Biomass Support Unit
Biomass e-trading platform operational

1. Inter-institutional Biomass Support Unit has been established within the Ministry of Mining and Energy, staffed and in full operation.
2. No training modules and seminars on Biomass Energy for local municipalities and entrepreneurs (planned for 2016/2017)
3. No new course on biomass energy at the University of Belgrade and Novi Sad (planned for 2016/2017)
4. Public awareness raising campaign on biomass energy initiated
4.1. International conference 'Sustainable Growth from Biomass' was organized on 26 March, 2015 in the Serbian Chamber of Commerce and Industry in cooperation with Finnish Embassy in Serbia and Standing Conference of Towns and Municipalities.
4.2. Project web site has been established (http://biomasa.undp.org.rs).
5. Grant Agreement for non-credit related activities was signed between the UNDP and Serbian Chamber of Commerce and Industry for the Project "Development and Operation of the Biomass Web Portal along with the Online Biomass Trading Platform and Biomass e-trading Platform" in June 2015.

description.narrative: Stronger and more effective secondary legislation related to biomass energy is developed and approved and adopted

1. Status of adoption of secondary legislation, technical standards, policies and regulations for biomass projects and biomass supply including required amendments to existing bylaws, technical standards and technical regulations for energy/power facilities.
2. Established licensing procedures

comment.narrative:
1. No secondary legislation, technical standards, policies and regulations for biomass projects and biomass supply including required amendments to existing bylaws, technical standards and technical regulations for energy/power facilities.
2. Lack of integrated licensing procedures

1. Proposed secondary legislation, technical standards, policies and regulations for biomass projects and biomass supply including required amendments to existing bylaws, technical standards and technical regulations for energy/power facilities
2. Appropriate licensing procedures; biomass to energy systems are in place and investors have clarified and simplified process to follow

1. Elaboration of the new Government decrees in line with recently adopted new Energy law is in course:
1.1 The Decree on Incentives for Privileged Power Producers which will prescribe in more detail the categories of privileged power producers, incentives, conditions for their achievement, manner of setting the incentive period, rights and obligations derived from the incentives for privileged power producers and other energy entities, set the content of relevant contracts etc. is in course.
1.2 The Decree on Conditions and Procedure for Acquiring the Status of Privileged Electricity Producer
1.3 The Decree on on Setting the Models of Power Purchase Agreements and Pre-Agreements
1.4 The Decree on Guarantee of Origin for Electricity Produced from Renewable Energy Sources
The above listed decrees are of decisive significance for use of biomass, and renewable energy in general.
1.5 Project partner institution - Institute for Standardization (ISS) has started activities on the GEF Project in May 2015. European Standard EN 16325 has been translated. Process of its adoption by technical commission A242 of ISS has been initiated. It will provide basis for Decree on Guarantee of Origin for Electricity Produced from Renewable Energy Sources which is to be adopted by the Government of RS to complement recently adopted Energy Law. Elaboration of the said Decree is in course.
2. No Licensing procedure established (planned for 2016/2017)

Accelerating Change: Support for Public Administration Reform and Local Self-Government Development
Delivery for Change – Strengthening the Ministry of Public Administration and Local Self-Government (MPALSG) for a Changed Public Administration in Serbia
capital of a political entity
Anti corruption

1. Number of analytical diagnostic reports developed and endorsed by the Ministry, to be used for internal restructuring 2. New organizational structure established based on developed diagnostics (yes/no) 3. Number of trainings held for Ministry management in support of its new change management function, both internally and externally across the public administration 4. Developed phased strengthening plan for the Ministry's change management function

comment.narrative: Ministry of Public Administration and Local Self Government (MPLASG) has a sub-optimal operational and management structure to adequately implement reforms and fulfill its ambitious mandate defined by the Public Administration Reform Strategy and Action Plan.

1. Developed at least 3 diagnostic reports outlining: a) stakeholder expectations from the Ministry with respect to the PAR Strategy and Action Plan, b) functional review and resource reallocation plan, and c) training needs assessment. 2. Adopted new Rulebook on Internal Organization and Job Classification, in line with expert analytics 3. At least 2 trainings in management skills and 2 trainings in soft skills delivered to Ministry senior management (attendance at least 12 managers on average) 4. Phased strengthening plan endorsed by the Ministry

1. Developed 7 analytical reports: functional analysis, resource allocation analysis, business process analysis, national and sub-national stakeholder analysis, a training needs assessment, and a workload assessment. All expert reports presented to top Ministry management (including Minister) and officially endorsed by the Ministry. 2.Developed expert inputs to the new Rulebook on Internal Organization and Job Classification, including organigrammes and draft job descriptions; new Rulebook detailing the new organizational structure officially adopted. 3. Three trainings in management skills delivered to Ministry management (average participation 15 people), 2 soft skills trainings delivered to management, 1 soft skills training delivered to entire Ministry staff. 4. Phased strengthening plan prepared, presented, and endorsed by the Ministry.

description.narrative: Support to local self-government development as per request from MPALSG for programming an intervention in support of horizontal and vertical coordination with the local level.

title.narrative: Increased Resilience to Respond to Emergency Situations

description.narrative: The project will support recovery, reduce vulnerability and increase resilience in flood affected municipalities through area-based, multi-dimensional and integrated approaches. integrated approaches in 27 municipalities;

title.narrative: Project Document - Increased Resilience to Respond to Emergency Situations
Increased Resilience to Respond to Emergency Situations
Increased Resilience to Respond to Emergency Situations

description.narrative: Contribute to the recovery actions through provision of direct assistance to municipalities affected by floods.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Number municipalities with improved infrastructure 2. Municipal capacities for disaster preparedness enhanced in line with the EU Civil Protection Mechanism 3. Number of NGOs that advocate women participation in disaster risk management and planning 4. Number of Landslides mapped and rehabilitated

comment.narrative: During the May 2014, heavy rains hit Serbia, causing large scale flooding. The floods had instantaneous and direct effects resulting in the total destruction of houses, bridges and sections of roads (Krupanj and Šabac); widespread flooding of both urban areas (Obrenovac) and rural areas (Šabac); and widespread landslides (Krupanj and Bajina Bašta). Floods also caused significant economic hardship for much of the population and disproportionally affected poor and vulnerable people. The Recovery Needs Assessment, that encompassed 24 assessed municipalities, estimated the total damage in all affected municipalities at € 1.7 billion.

1. At least 15 municipalities improved water systems, sanitation and public infrastructure 2. Capacity of at least 20 municipalities improved in community early warning, rescue and evacuation 3.10 NGOs 4. 400 landslides mapped through satellite imagery systems; 100 landslides assessed through filed visits

1. 18 municipalities improved water systems, sanitation and public infrastructure (27 infrastructural projects) 2. 10 trainings for 30 municipality representatives conducted 3. 11 NGOs (e.g. Women Rescue Team established) 4. 1000 landslides mapped; project design for rehabilitation of 5 landslides initiated

comment.narrative: 1. Insufficient capacities of decision makers and no capacities of consumer associations and consumers in general for implementation of chemicals safety policy. 2. No mechanism in place for data collection in the field of chemicals safety in products

1. At least three consumer associations,10 journalists, National Chemicals Safety Coordination Team trained for improved implementation of advanced policy on chemicals safety in products; 2. Data collection and information dissemination improved on chemicals safety in products of general use, through the definition of related documents and piloting of information platform;

1. Three consumer associations are better acquainted with options for improved implementation of chemicals safety in products policy; Ten journalists gained knowledge for improved information dissemination on chemicals safety in products of general use on Serbian market; General public/consumers are familiar with the legal rights for access to information on chemicals safety in products on Serbian market; 2. Formal procedures established for information dissemination and collection of data related to chemicals in products of general use on Serbian market;

description.narrative: Citizen centric policy measures

title.narrative: PRODOC Mngmt of CitizenCentric Policy Measures

description.narrative: The overall objective of the project is to enable the Government to drive forward a set of citizen-centric policy measures and interventions, which will make a substantial difference to the quality of life experienced by Serbia’s citizens.
capital of a political entity
Anti corruption
1. Number of Government program priorities for which the Prime Minister's Office is receiving expert support

comment.narrative: The Center of Government lacks capacity for pushing forth fast-track reforms to the benefit of citizens and strengthening coordination among various government agents to this end, which has been identified as a key barrier to successful reforms by national and international assessments.
1. Prime Minister's Office provided with expert support in all 5 priority areas, by at least 1 senior and 1 junior expert.

1.1 Prime Minister's Office endorsed six UNDP expert teams, each comprising 1 senior and 2-3 junior experts (21 experts in total); all 5 priority areas covered, plus an additional team providing legal expertise and analytical support. 1.2 Each team established firm and regular communication with relevant ministries and other key stakeholders, and identified 2-3 priority projects for mid-term coordination and implementation support.

The Prime Minister Office provided with expert support in delivering in 5 government priority sectors by a cluster of teama consisting of at least a Team Leader, one senior and one junior expert per area of expertise addressing priorities stated by PM.
